main_story.title: India's Solar Revolution Races Five Years Ahead of Schedule
main_story.content:
India just did something remarkable: In the first nine months of 2025 alone, the country installed 29.5 gigawatts of new solar capacity. To put that in perspective, that's more solar power than the entire amount ever installed by countries like France or South Korea.

The surge is being driven by two major factors: solar panel prices have hit record lows, and the government has streamlined the permitting process to make it easier to build solar farms. The result? India is on pace to exceed its 2030 renewable energy targets five years early.

Solar power now supplies over 10% of India's electricity, and that percentage keeps growing. For a country of 1.4 billion people, this represents a massive shift in how energy is produced and consumed.

But India isn't stopping at ground-level solar. On the Tibetan Plateau, China has built something extraordinary: 420 square kilometers of solar panels and wind farms—an area seven times the size of Manhattan. The Talatan Solar Park alone produces enough electricity to power every household in Chicago.

What makes this high-altitude installation special? The thin air and intense sunlight at high elevations make solar panels more efficient. Combined with new hydropower dams and pumped-storage projects, Qinghai province now meets nearly all its energy needs from renewable sources. The cheap, carbon-free power is even attracting AI data centers to the region.

And there's more innovation happening underwater and on water. China launched the world's first commercial underwater data center off Hainan, using seawater cooling to slash energy use while boosting capacity for AI operations. Meanwhile in Germany, engineers activated a 1.8-megawatt vertical floating solar plant on a Bavarian quarry lake, combining high storm resistance with ecological benefits for aquatic life.

For young people watching these developments, the message is clear: the clean energy transition isn't some distant future goal—it's happening right now, faster than most experts predicted. Countries are proving that renewable energy can power everything from households to data centers, and they're doing it at a scale and speed that seemed impossible just a decade ago.

mini_articles.title: Renewables Cut Fossil Fuel Imports for 100+ Nations
mini_articles.content: A new analysis finds clean energy growth has cut fossil-fuel import dependence in more than 100 nations since 2019, saving around $500 billion in annual costs. The shift, driven by rapid solar and wind deployment, has improved trade balances and energy security from Europe to Asia.

mini_articles.title: World on Track for Record Renewable Expansion
mini_articles.content: Global renewable power capacity grew by 15% in 2024, its fastest pace in history. The world is now roughly two-thirds of the way toward tripling renewable capacity by 2030, according to a new IRENA report. The momentum shows no signs of slowing.

mini_articles.title: James Webb Telescope May Have Spotted Dark Stars
mini_articles.content: Astronomers have identified four ultra-distant objects that may be supermassive dark stars—theoretical giants powered by annihilating dark matter rather than fusion. If confirmed, they would mark the first evidence of stars sustained by dark matter energy and could explain rapid black hole formation just 300 million years after the Big Bang.

mini_articles.title: Two New Cancer Therapies Show Promise
mini_articles.content: Researchers developed a therapy using naturally occurring enzymes to weaken cancer cell membranes, making tumors more vulnerable to immune defenses without harming healthy tissue. Separately, MIT and Harvard engineered natural killer cells that hunt tumors without triggering dangerous immune storms, wiping out most lymphoma cells in mouse models within weeks.
